snippet.title: $7000 credit card fraud was 'revenge' for domestic violence against mum
snippet.content: A TEENAGER has told a court she used a credit card belonging to her mother's partner, spending almost $7000, in revenge for alleged acts of domestic violence. The 19-year-old Maroochydore woman pleaded guilty in Maroochydore Magistrates Court yesterday to fraud. She cannot be named to protect the identity of her mother, who has domestic violence orders against the man. The court heard the woman used the man's credit cards a total of 212 times between May 2016 and June 2017, racking up $6997.53 in bills for goods and services including make-up, clothing, food and Uber rides. The man cancelled his credit card three times after seeing the fraudulent transactions, but each time a new card arrived the woman took down the details. In June, the man reported the matter to police, suspecting the teenager. In an interview with police, the woman said the man had subjected her mother to domestic abuse. Westpac had not compensated the man, and he sought full restitution of the money spent. The woman had no criminal history, and the court heard she was seeking help for anxiety and depression. The man is facing domestic violence-related charges. Magistrate Rod Madsen told the woman she was lucky she was caught before the spending exceeded $10,000, or she could have faced a prison sentence for the "foolish" crime. Mr Madsen said a domestic violence situation was not an excuse to break the law. "You might have thought two wrongs make a right, but it doesn't," he said. "Just let the police do their job... it certainly hasn't helped." He sentenced the woman to a year on probation and ordered restitution be paid in full.
